solution_01_data_basics/01_counting/07_read_histogram_discrete_v3

video

The first 4 questions involve adding up frequencies of the indicated intervals. The last 4 questions can be done by guessing and checking until something works.


  1. (ANS=47) There are 47 measurements less than 6.5. So, \(\#[\mathbf{x}<6.5]=47\).
  2. (ANS=47) There are 47 measurements more than 3.5. So, \(\#[\mathbf{x}>3.5]=47\).
  3. (ANS=13) There are 13 measurements closer than 1 units from 3.5. So, \(\#[|\mathbf{x}-3.5|<1]=13\).
  4. (ANS=32) There are 32 measurements further than 2.5 units from 4. So, \(\#[|\mathbf{x}-4|>2.5]=32\).
  5. (ANS=4.5) A boundary at \(b=4.5\) has 31 measurements less than it. So, \(\#[\mathbf{x}<4.5]=31\).
  6. (ANS=4.5) A boundary at \(b=4.5\) has 39 measurements more than it. So, \(\#[\mathbf{x}>4.5]=39\).
  7. (ANS=1) An interval with radius \(r=1\) around center 3.5 contains 13 measurements. So, \(\#[|\mathbf{x}-3.5|<1]=13\).
  8. (ANS=1.5) An interval with radius \(r=1.5\) around center 3 excludes 48 measurements. So, \(\#[|\mathbf{x}-3|>1.5]=48\).
